desc.size: Biennial or perennial herb, 20 - 80 cm tall, erect.

part.partText: hairy. Usually single but occasionally two or three arise from the base.
short-stalked, oblong, hairy, in a rosette.
alternate, upright, clasping the stem, stalkless, 1 - 3 cm long, oblong to lance-shaped, margins toothed on lower leaves, margins becoming smooth on upper leaves, lower leaves hairy.
in loosely branched clusters, white or yellowish white, 3 - 5 mm long. Petals 4. Stamens 6: 4 tall, 2 short.
a narrow pod, erect or pressed against the stem, 3 - 5 cm long, 0.7 - 1.1 mm wide, linear, flat. Seeds in 1 row.

similarSpecies.comments: Arabis hirsuta is distinguished from A. hirsuta var. adpressipilis by not having appressed hairs.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Extremely rare in the Chicago Region because of the scarcity of its special habitats. It grows on shaded, moss-covered limestone boulders along the borders of streams in small rock canyons. It also grows on the vertical walls of limestone canyons. Another habitat is shaded floodplains. In other parts of its range it is found in moist, sandy soil.

etymology.comments: Arabis comes from the Latin word for Arabia (where some species of these herbs originated). Hirsuta means hairy.
